questions.text: A patient who presents with a painful, progressively enlarging growth from her left upper tibia is suspected to have chondrosarcoma and subjected to a biopsy and examination. The report states, “presence of osteoclast-type giant cells with intralesional bone formation”. Which of the following types of chondrosarcoma does this patient have?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 3: Clear cell

EXPLANATION:

The presence of osteoclast-type giant cells with intralesional bone formation is seen in clear-cell chondrosarcoma.

Chondrosarcoma:

  • Chondrosarcomas are malignant cartilage-producing tumours.
  • The majority of them have mutations in IDH1 and IDH2 genes.
  • It is the second most common malignant matrix-producing tumour of the bone.
  • Age: 40 years or older
  • Sex: Higher predominance in males
  • The clear cell and mesenchymal variants occur in younger people in their teens or 20s.
  • Chondrosarcomas commonly arise in the axial skeleton, especially the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs.
  • The popcorn/honey comb matrix is a finding in chondrosarcoma, characterized by irregular calcifications within the cartilage matrix.
  • Histologically, they are classified into 4 types.

 

Conventional (Option 1)

Dedifferentiated (Option 4)

Neoplastic cartilage infiltrates the marrow space and surrounds the pre-existing bony trabeculae.

 

Low-grade chondrosarcoma

with a second, high-grade component that does not produce cartilage.

Clear-cell (Option 3)

Mesenchymal (Option 2)

It contains sheets of large, malignant chondrocytes with abundant clear cytoplasm, numerous osteoclast-type giant cells, and intralesional bone formation.

Composed of islands of well-differentiated hyaline cartilage surrounded by sheets of primitive appearing small round cells.

questions.text:
Match the tumours in column A to their genetic alterations in Column B


	
		
			
			Tumor
			
			
			Translocation
			
		
		
			
			A) Ewing's Sarcoma
			
			
			1) t(x;18)
			
		
		
			
			B) Rhabdomyosarcoma
			
			
			2) t(12;16)
			
		
		
			
			C) Liposarcoma
			
			
			3) t(1;13)
			
		
		
			
			D) Synovial Sarcoma
			
			
			4) t(11;22)
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 3: A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Tumour

Translocation

Ewing's Sarcoma
  • t(11;22)
  • Fusion of the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11 leads to oncogenesis.

Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • t(1;13)

Liposarcoma
  • t(12;16)

Synovial Sarcoma
  • t(x;18)
  • The fusion of the SS18 gene on chromosome 18 with the SSX gene on the X-chromosome promotes oncogenic transformation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, presents with a sudden onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling in his right big toe. The right big toe is red, swollen, and extremely tender to touch. There is no fever or other systemic symptoms. He enjoys red meat and seafood, and he drinks alcholol regularly. All of the following are true about his diagnosis except?

choices.text: Deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints.
Rhomboid-shaped, weakly positively birefringent under polarised light confirms the diagnosis.

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 3: Rhomboid-shaped, weakly positively birefringent under polarised light confirms the diagnosis.

 

EXPLANATION:

The patient's presentation is suggestive of acute gout.

 

Feature

Gout

Pseudogout

Aetiology

Deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals

Deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals

Commonly Affected Joints

First metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe), ankles, knees

Knees, wrists, hips, shoulders, elbows

Crystal Characteristics

Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent under polarised light

Rhomboid-shaped, weakly positively birefringent under polarised light (Option 3)

Serum Findings

Elevated uric acid levels (Option 4)

Often, normal calcium and phosphorus levels

Risk Factors

High purine diet, alcohol consumption, obesity, diuretics (thiazides & loop diuretics) (Option 2), genetic predisposition

Age, joint trauma, familial predisposition, metabolic disorders (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis)

Acute Attack Presentation

Sudden, severe pain, redness, swelling, and warmth in the affected joint

Sudden, severe pain, redness, swelling, and warmth in the affected joint

questions.text: All of the following are true about rhabdomyosarcoma except?

choices.text: It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children.
Positive IHC staining for desmin and myogenin.
It commonly presents in the extremities of children and adolescents.
It has a benign clinical course and rarely metastasizes.

questions.solution:
CORRECT OPTION: Option 4: It has a benign clinical course and rarely metastasizes

 

EXPLANATION:

 

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a malignant tumour arising from skeletal muscle progenitors.
  • It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and adolescents (Option 1).
  • It commonly presents in the extremities (Option 3).
  • Types:
    • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.
    • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.
    • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma.
    • Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • The tumours are often large, soft, and infiltrative, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage.
  • Microscopy: Small, round to spindle-shaped cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, sometimes with a myxoid stroma are also seen.
  • IHC Positive Markers: Desmin, myogenin, MyoD1, and muscle-specific actin (Option 2).
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma has an aggressive clinical course and can metastasise, particularly to the lungs, bone marrow, and lymph nodes.

 

The image below shows alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of heavy menstrual bleeding and a sensation of pelvic pressure. She reports that her periods have become increasingly heavy. There is no significant past medical history, and she is not currently on any medication.Ultrasound reveals a heterogeneous, hypoechoic mass within the uterus. A histology image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 4: Leiomyoma

 

EXPLANATION:

Leiomyoma, also known as a uterine fibroid, is a benign smooth muscle tumour that commonly occurs in the uterus. These tumors are composed of well-differentiated smooth muscle cells and are the most common benign tumours in women of reproductive age.

 

  • Genetic Factors: Mutations in MED12 gene.
  • Hormonal Influence: Estrogen and progesterone
  • Appearance: Leiomyomas are typically firm, well-circumscribed, round, and whorled masses.

  • Location: Leiomyomas can be found in various locations within the uterus:
    • Intramural: Within the uterine wall.
    • Submucosal: Beneath the lining of the uterine cavity.
    • Subserosal: Beneath the outer covering of the uterus.
  • Cellular Structure: Leiomyomas are composed of spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells arranged in interlacing fascicles.

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option 1: Adenomyosis.

  • Typically presents with a uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus.
  • Histologically shows endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, not just smooth muscle cells.

 

Option 2: Leiomyosarcoma.

  • Rare malignant smooth muscle tumor.
  • Histologically shows significant atypia, high mitotic rate, and areas of necrosis.
  • Patients may present with rapidly growing mass and systemic symptoms.

 

Option 3: Endometrial carcinoma.

  • Typically presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, especially postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Histology shows malignant endometrial glandular cells, not smooth muscle cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with an enlarging mass in his left thigh for the last three months. Physical examination revealed a non-tender, palpable mass with indistinct borders. He has a prior history of mass excision in the same location. A biopsy of the lesion is obtained. Based on the presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 2: Liposarcoma

 

EXPLANATION:

Liposarcoma:

  • Malignant adipose tissue tumour.
  • Most common adult sarcoma.
  • Typically occur in the sixth and seventh decades.
  • Develop in proximal extremities and retroperitoneum.
  • Three subtypes:
    • Well-differentiated: chromosome 12 amplification, including p53 inhibitor MDM2.
    • Myxoid: t(12;16) translocation.
    • Pleomorphic
  • Biopsy:
    • Well-differentiated: Mature adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells.
    • Myxoid: Abundant basophilic extracellular matrix, arborizing capillaries (chicken wire blood vessels) and primitive fat cells (lipoblasts).

Pleomorphic: Sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei and immature adipocytes, called lipoblasts.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option 1: Lipoma is the most common benign soft tissue tumor of fat in adults and, upon biopsy, reveals mature fat cells with peripheral nuclei.

 

Option 3:

  • Leiomyosarcomas are malignant, painless, firm masses arising from smooth muscle.
  • These tumours are composed of eosinophilic spindle cells with blunt-ended, cigar shaped nuclei.

 

Option 4: Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumour of fibroblasts with a "herringbone" architecture.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with worsening pain in her right tibia over the past few months. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the proximal right tibia. Biopsy results show blood-filled cystic spaces lined by fibrous septa containing giant cells. All the following statements are true regarding this condition except?

choices.text: Characterised by uniloculated blood-filled spaces with eggshell appearance on x-ray.
Often aggressively growing and are frequently discovered in vertebral bodies.
Majority cases are found associated with USP6 gene involvement in chromosome 17
Nearly one third patients have a distinctive basophilic metaplastic matrix known as blue bone

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 1: Characterised by uniloculated blood-filled spaces with eggshell appearance on x-ray

EXPLANATION:

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC):

  • Affects all age groups, with most cases in adolescence.
  • Characterised by multiloculated blood-filled spaces (Option 1).
  • Location: Femur, tibia, and posterior vertebral body (Option 2).
  • Genetics:
    • Chromosome 17p13 rearrangements result in fusion of the USP6 coding region in 70% cases. (Option 3)
    • Highly expressed osteoblast genes like CDH11.
    • USP6 upregulates NF-κB activity.
  • Biopsy:
    • Blood-filled cystic spaces separated by thin, tan-white septa made up of spindle cells, osteoclast-like giant cells.
    • Approximately one-third cases contain densely calcified, basophilic metaplastic matrix called blue bone (Option 4).
    • Necrosis is uncommon.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with left knee pain for several months. Physical examination reveals tenderness and X-ray demonstrates metaphyseal lesion of the distal femur. A biopsy image of the lesion is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 3: Non-ossifying fibroma

 

EXPLANATION:

 

A non-ossifying fibroma is the most likely diagnosis.

A biopsy finding suggestive of storiform pattern made by benign spindle cells with scattered osteoclast-type giant cells.

 

Non-Ossifying Fibroma:

 

  • Developmental defect in which fibrous connective tissue replaces bone.
  • Age group: children and adolescents.
  • Arise eccentrically in the metaphysis of the distal femur and proximal tibia.
  • Masses growing to 5 or 6 cm are classified as non-ossifying fibromas.
  • Morphology:
    • Gross: Yellow-brown.
    • Microscopic: Bland fibroblasts arranged in a storiform (pinwheel) pattern and macrophages with foamy cytoplasm or multinucleated giant cells with osteoblastic rimming.
    • Hemosiderin is commonly present.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding fibrous dysplasia?

 


	It is a malignant tumour with components of normal bone unable to differentiate into mature structures
	Associated with CSF 1 R gene mutation and soft tissue myxoma.
	Typically occurs in older individuals causing bones to become weak and easily fractured.
	Histopathological examination shows woven bone trabeculae with disorganised growth plates.
	Females commonly presents with precocious puberty and irregular dark skin lesions.
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 4: Statements 4 and 5

EXPLANATION:

Fibrous Dysplasia:

  • It is a benign childhood tumour caused by GNAS1 mutations, characterised by immature normal bone components and disorganised growth plates, linked to McCune- Albright syndrome.
  • The components of normal bone are present, but do not differentiate into mature structure.
  • Types: Can be monostotic or polyostotic.
    • Monostotic: more common in craniofacial bones and femur.
    • Polystotic: commonly affected are pelvis, femur and tibia.
  • McCuneAlbright Syndrome:
    • Commonly presented as precocious sexual development, mainly in girls.
    • Polyostotic disease associated with café-au-lait skin pigmentations and endocrine abnormalities.
    • Café-au-lait macules: dark large macules with irregular serpiginous borders on the same side of the body as the bone lesions.
  • Mazabraud syndrome: Fibrous dysplasia associated with soft tissue myxomas.
  • Morphology:
  • Gross:
    • Tan-white, gritty structure.
    • Nodules of hyaline cartilage: disorganized growth plates.
    • Shepherd's crook deformity
  • Microscopy:
    • Curvilinear trabeculae of woven bone that lack conspicuous osteoblastic rimming in a background of fibrous tissue (Chinese letter pattern).

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with worsening lower back pain and difficulty walking for the last few months. Molecular analysis revealed brachyury gene expression. A biopsy image of the lesion is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 1: Chordoma

 

EXPLANATION:

 

The clinical vignette, biopsy showing cords of epithelial cells, abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, vacuoles, and extracellular myxoid matrix is suggestive of chordoma.

  • Biopsy shows cords of epithelial cells, abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, vacuoles, and extracellular myxoid matrix

Chordoma:

  • It is a low-grade, slow-growing but locally invasive and locally aggressive tumour.
  • They arise from the remnants of the notochord and occur along the midline spinal axis between the clivus and the sacrum, anterior to the spinal cord.
  • Genetics: Brachyury gene
  • Morphology:
    • Microscopy: Physaliferous cells (cells with bubbly or vacuolated appearance), abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, cords of epithelioid cells, vacuoles, and extracellular myxoid matrix.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding normal bone and bone marrow are true?

 

1. Bone marrow contains a rich network of blood vessels, nerves, and lymphatics, supporting its role as a hematopoietic organ.

 

2. Osteoblasts are responsible for bone formation, while osteoclasts are involved in bone resorption.

 

3. Hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow give rise to some blood cell lineages.

 

4. Bone marrow lacks hematopoietic elements and serves primarily as a site for fat storage.

 

5. Bone remodelling is solely regulated by hormonal factors.
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 1: Statements 1 and 2 are correct

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Correct statements:

Statement

Explanation

1. Bone marrow contains a rich network of blood vessels, nerves, and lymphatics, supporting its role as a hematopoietic organ.

Bone marrow is highly vascularised and innervated, providing the necessary microenvironment for hematopoiesis and immune function.

2. Osteoblasts are responsible for bone formation, while osteoclasts are involved in bone resorption.

Osteoblasts are bone-forming cells, while osteoclasts are responsible for bone resorption, leading to bone remodelling and maintenance of bone density.

 

Incorrect statements:

Statement

Correct Explanation

3. Hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow give rise to some cell lineages

Hematopoietic stem cells give rise to all blood cell lineages, not just some.

4. Bone marrow lacks hematopoietic elements and serves primarily as a site for fat storage.

Bone marrow is a major site for hematopoiesis, where blood cells are produced. While some bone marrow does contain adipocytes for fat storage, this is not its primary function.

5. Bone remodelling is solely regulated by mechanical stress and does not involve hormonal regulation.

Mechanical stress and hormonal factors, both regulate bone remodelling, including parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcitonin. Hormonal regulation plays a significant role in maintaining bone homeostasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about enchondromas?

choices.text: Maffucci syndrome can also co-exist with brain glioma.
Mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase enzyme genes are common.
Histology shows hyaline cartilage encased by reactive bone.
Ollier's disease presents as solitary juxta-cortical enchondromas.

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 4

 

EXPLANATION:

 

  • Chondroma is a benign tumour of hyaline cartilage that occurs in bones of endochondral origin.
  • Enchondromas: Tumours can arise within the medullary cavity,
  • Juxtacortical chondromas: Tumors arising on the bone surfaceBoth Maffucci syndrome and Ollier’s disease are characterised by multiple enchondromas (not solitary).


 

Option 1: Maffucci syndrome can be distinguished from Ollier’s disease by the presence of other neoplasms like spindle cell hemangioma, brain glioma, etc.

 

Option 2: Mutations in the IDH1 & IDH2 genes which code for isocitrate dehydrogenase enzyme are seen commonly in enchondromas.

 

Option 3: Radiograph shows a characteristic nodule of hyaline cartilage encased by reactive bone, which can also be confirmed by histopathological examination as shown in the image.

         Benign Cartilage

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents with a swelling on his left tibia. An X-ray of the leg shows a destructive process with indistinct borders and an onion-skin pattern of the periosteal bone. A biopsy was performed, as shown in the image below. Identify the true statements regarding this condition.




	It is a malignant tumour characterised by primitive round cells with obvious differentiation.
	It affects boys more than girls.
	More than 90% of the cases are caused due to t(11;22)(q24;q12) mutation.
	The presence of rounded cell clusters with a central fibrillary core indicates neuroectodermal differentiation.
	Chemotherapy-induced necrosis is a negative prognostic indicator.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario suggests Ewing’s sarcoma.
  • The correct statements regarding this condition are 2, 3, 4.

 

Ewing’s sarcoma:

  • It is a malignant bone tumour characterised by primitive round cells without obvious differentiation. (Statement 1)
  • Approximately 80% of patients are younger than 20 years of age.
  • Males are affected slightly more often than Females. (Statement 2)
  • It usually arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and in the flat bones of the pelvis and presents as a painful, enlarging mass.
  • The most common mutation (>90% of the cases) is t(11;22)(q24;q12). (Statement 3)
  • Morphology:
    • The tumour is soft, tan-white, and frequently contains areas of haemorrhage and necrosis.
    • It comprises sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm that may be clear due to abundant glycogen.
    • Homer-Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) are rounded cell clusters with a central fibrillary core, their presence indicates neuroectodermal differentiation. (Statement 4)
    • Specific markers: CD99+ (MIC2) positive.
    • Fibrous septae may also be present, but there is little stroma.
    • Geographic necrosis may be prominent.
  • Chemotherapy-induced necrosis is a positive prognostic indicator. (Statement 5)

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a lesion arising from the right distal femur is given as the image below with such characteristic cells. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows numerous multinucleated giant cells in a bone lesion, suggesting osteoclastoma/giant cell tumour.

 

If thesecells are present in a tumour arising from cartilage, it is likely to be chondrosarcoma.

 

Giant cell tumour (Osteoclastoma):

 

  • It is a benign but locally aggressive tumour characterised by numerous multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells.
  • It occurs in the third to fifth decades of life.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • The neoplastic cells are primitive osteoblast precursors that express high levels of RANKL, promoting the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts.
    • This increased activity of osteoclasts is responsible for the tumour being highly lytic and expansile due to uncontrolled bone resorption.
  • Giant cell tumours develop within the epiphysis and may extend into the metaphysis.
    • Mostly located near the knee, involving the distal femur or proximal tibia.
    • Although rare, they can metastasize to the lungs, but typically regress spontaneously and are rarely fatal.
  • Morphology:
    • Grossly, the tumours are large, red-brown masses that frequently undergo cystic degeneration.

Histologically, the tumours consist of uniform oval mononuclear tumour cells and abundant osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei.

questions.text: A patient presented with a hard mass over the right tibia, and subsequent imaging revealed the presence of sessile growth in the bone. Biopsy is done later, which shows the presence of “cartilage cap” over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: A) Osteochondroma

EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation is suggestive of osteochondroma, characterised by the presence of of sessile growth in the bone

 

Osteochondroma (Exostosis):

 

  • Most common benign tumour attached to the skeleton by a bony stalk capped by cartilage.
  • About 85% of osteochondromas are solitary and sporadic, with the remainder as part of autosomal dominant multiple hereditary exostosis syndrome.
  • Males are affected three times more often than females.
  • The most common site is the metaphysis near the growth plate of long tubular bones (knee > pelvis > scapula > ribs), where they tend to have short stalks.
  • Hereditary exostoses are associated with germline loss-of-function mutations in the EXT1 or EXT2 gene, which encode glycosyltransferases involved in heparan sulfate synthesis.
  • Morphology:
    • It is a sessile or pedunculated tumour in bones of endochondral origin.
    • Hyaline cartilage cap surrounded by pericondrium.
  • Histology: It resembles a disorganized growth plate, and they undergo enchondral ossification, with the newly formed bone making up the inner portion of the head and stalk.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with persistent knee pain and swelling of two months duration. The pain is severe at night and not relieved by NSAIDs. A biopsy was performed, and it showed pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and bizarre giant cells producing unmineralised osteoid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option C Osteosarcoma

EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation is suggestive of osteosarcoma, characterised by presence of pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and bizarre giant cells producing unmineralised osteoid

Osteosarcoma:

  • It is the most common primary malignant tumour of bone and accounts for approximately 20% of bone cancers.
  • Age distribution: Bimodal.
    • 75% of cases - before 20 years of age.
    • Slight rise of incidence in older adults with Paget disease, bone infarcts & prior radiation.
  • Tumours usually arise in the metaphyseal region of the long bones; almost 50% are near the knee in the distal femur or proximal tibia.
  • Genetic associations:
    • RB gene (most common): 70%.
    • TP53.
    • CDKN2A (also known as INK4a).
    • MDM2 and CDK4.
  • Morphology:
    • Osteosarcomas are bulky, gritty, grey-white tumours that often contain haemorrhage and cystic degeneration.
    • Histology demonstrate pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, bizarre tumour giant cells, and abundant mitoses.
    • Extensive necrosis and intravascular invasion are also common.
    • Diagnosis of osteosarcoma requires the presence of malignant tumour cells producing unmineralised osteoid or mineralised bone.
  • Osteosarcoma metastasises hematogenously to the lungs, bones, brain, and other sites.

Osteoid Osteoma (Option A): Small benign tumor. Severe night pain, but typically relieved by NSAIDs. Histology: woven bone and osteoblasts, but no marked pleomorphism or malignant features. No unmineralised osteoid with atypia

Osteoblastoma (Option B): Benign, larger than osteoid osteoma. May cause chronic pain, less responsive to NSAIDs than osteoid osteoma. Histology: Similar to osteoid osteoma but larger, more vascular, no marked pleomorphism or malignant osteoid production

Osteoclastoma  (Option D):(Giant Cell Tumor) Typically occurs in young adults (20–40 years). Epiphysis of long bones, not metaphysis. Histology: multinucleated giant cells, but no malignant osteoid, and no pleomorphic malignant osteoblasts

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with persistent pain in his right leg that worsens at night and is partially relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Imaging is given below. Based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings, which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It has a predilection for the appendicular skeleton.
It is less than 2 cm in diameter.
It commonly affects the axial skeleton
Pain is relieved on taking aspirin

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 3: It commonly affects the axial skeleton

 

EXPLANATION:

  • The imaging shows a small, well-defined bone tumor, and the clinical presentation is consistent with osteoid osteoma, which is characterized by nocturnal pain.
  • These are rarely found in the axial skeleton, with a much higher predilection for the appendicular skeleton(limbs).

Features

Osteoid Osteoma

Osteoblastoma

Size

Less than 2 cm

More than 2 cm

Site

Femur or Tibia

Spine

Pain

Nocturnal pain

Dull pain

On treatment

Relieved about taking aspirin

Not relieved on taking aspirin
Imaging

The image below shows the histological features of osteoid osteoma, including spongy (woven) bone with dilated blood vessels.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with Gardner’s syndrome except?

choices.text: Colon polyps with risk of malignancy

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 3: Enchondroma

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Gardner syndrome is an autosomal dominant phenotypic variant of familial adenomatous polyposis(FAP), along with various extraintestinal manifestations.

 

The key features of Gardner's syndrome include

 

  • Gastrointestinal polyps (High risk of malignancy)
  • Multiple osteomas, especially in the mandible, skull, and long bones.
  • Epidermoid cysts, fibromas, desmoid tumours, and other benign soft tissue tumours.
  • Dental abnormalities include supernumerary teeth, impacted teeth, odontomas, and congenitally missing teeth.
  • Increased risk of certain cancers, including thyroid, liver, and adrenal.

 

Osteomas are benign bone-forming tumours commonly occurring in the head, particularly in the skull and jaw bones. They are slow-growing, well-circumscribed, and primarily composed of mature lamellar bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a metaphyseal tumour?

choices.text: Giant cell tumour of the bone

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option 3: Giant cell tumour of the bone

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Classification of bone tumours:


 

Epiphyseal tumours

Metaphyseal tumours

Diaphyseal tumours
  • Giant cell tumour (GCT).
  • Chondroblastoma.
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma.
  • Simple bone cyst.
  • Osteosarcoma.
  • Fibrous dysplasia.
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst.
  • Osteochondroma.
  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Multiple myeloma.
  • Adamantinoma.
  • .
  • Ewing's Sarcoma.
  • Osteoid Osteoma.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a history of frequent fractures, bone pain, and difficulty walking. On examination, he has short stature and cranial nerve palsies. The radiograph is revealed below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and radiography showing generalised sclerosis and a bone-within-bone appearance is suggestive of osteopetrosis.

 

Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease:

  • Osteopetrosis is a group of rare genetic diseases characterised by reduced bone resorption due to deficient osteoclast development or function, leading to impaired bone remodelling and dense but brittle bones prone to fractures.
  • The inheritance patterns are as follows:
    • Autosomal dominant (Alberg-Schonberg disease): CLCN7.
    • Autosomal recessive: TCIRG1 and Carbonic anhydrase 2 (CA2).
    • X-linked: IKBKG.
  • Morphologically, affected bones lack a medullary canal, exhibit bulbous and misshapen ends, and show persistent primary spongiosa.

 

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option A):

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones that fracture easily, presenting with a history of fractures, blue sclerae, due to defects in type I collagen synthesis.

 

Rickets (Option C):

  • Rickets is a skeletal disorder primarily seen in children. It results from vitamin D deficiency, impaired calcium absorption, or phosphate deficiency and causes soft, weak bones.
  • Clinical features include skeletal deformities, delayed growth, and muscle weakness.

 

Paget disease of the bone (Option D):

  • Paget disease of bone is a chronic disorder characterised by excessive and disorganised bone remodelling, leading to enlarged and deformed bones.
  • Patients may present with bone pain, deformities, fractures, and rarely, complications such as osteosarcoma.
